On Fri, 6 Sep 2002, dph_of_rules wrote:

> http://www.cei.net/~dphofrules/PROTO.gif is the link to the GUI I have
> worked up so far for it.  Don't worry: I have two other separate forms
> for choosing which characters and which treasures to put on the
> screen.  Coding the command button shouldn't be a problem since I plan
> on stealing some of my own code I developed earlier.  Creating the
> text validation might be tricky, though.  I'm not too sure if giving
> the user the option of choosing the scenario type; I may redo that as
> a list box just to save time.

Visual Basic isn't the most cross-platform thing in existance, but if it
works, it works. We can always rewrite it in C later for use across
platforms. It looks good, though. The outside isn't really important, its
the inside that matters.

Terrain generation can also be incorporated into that later, but I think
most of us preffer coding in C than in VB. We'll get to that later,
though.

>
> Picking the grid file and dimensions is going to be tricky, though.  I
> am tempted to make the user pick an existing map to use and make the
> program read the grid file to pull out the available dimensions.
>

That works. Speaking of grids, I wrote a pixedit program yesterday. It
doesn't actually edit pixes yet, but it views them. Its pixedit.c in the
utils/ folder if you want to check it out. Latest in CVS works quite well.
This will also work for map grid files.

> Also, I'm wondering about allowing the program to pick random levels
> for the different types of objects if the user supplies the range.
>
> I'm also unsure of how to handle team numbers for the characters: Does
> each character get a randomly assigned team number; each character is
> on the same team as the user chooses; or the user chooses x number of
> random characters to be on team 1, x number of characters to be on
> team 2, etc?

I think the best thing would be to have an option for the amount of enemy
teams, then distribute foes randomly between them.

>
> Also, what about player positions/exits?  I am going to assume the
> user will have to add an exit pointing to another scenario or should
> the user get the choice about putting in one exit to whatever scenario
> level?  Also, should the program assign initial player start-up
> positions?
>

If start-up positions arn't specified, the game will scatter your team all
over the map randomly. If exits arn't specified, the only way to get out
of the level is to abort.

> Also, here's a list of my assumptions:
> 1)if a teleporter is choosen at random, you would always get a pair of
> teleporters (one by itself is useless unless you want to torment the
> player)
> 2)if a door has x level and is on team y, then there is a key that has
> x level and is on team y.  The same is true in reverse with respect to
> keys and doors. - [That presents any interesting question about how to
> handle doors and keys]
> 3)this program will not have intelligence enough not to place a
> character and treasure in a "bad" location.  If somebody wants to add
> that feature later, no problems.
> 4)the user adds text later.

Those are all reasonable assumptions and are easy to change in code.

>
> With the answers to these questions, I should have a program ready by
> September 13.

Cool. Do you want me to create a subproject for it on Sourceforge so that
it'll be easily accessable from the sourceforge project page? That would
also take care of hosting and all that stuff.


- Zardus
